title: How to become a better guitarist sooner - Quora

response.answer_text: I can tell you how you would not become awesome. Here’s a few steps: Start learning, but don’t practice, at all.Even if you practice, make sure the practice sessions get obstructed by phone calls and random fiddling with your smartphone.Start learning after 30Stop taking care of your guitarDon’t watch any guitar tutorials on youtubeI always wanted to learn to play the guitar, but never got the time and opportunity to do it. Actually, it was more due to laziness instead of the other reasons I’ve specified. Also, I had a hobby that effectively prevents people from spending time in other hobbies, e.g. video gaming. Eventually, when I did start taking lessons, I was in my 30s, and I found it very difficult to continue. First month was filled with enthusiasm and excitement; I bought an expensive nylon stringed Ibanez guitar, and I started practicing every day. But things started changing in the subsequent month. Me and 3 of my friends started together. All of us came from similar background, and we also were in the same age group. One of the main reasons for starting the classes was the group we had. We encouraged each other and held group practice sessions. Things evidently were not the same when one of us decided to quit. Eventually, only I survived—the other three just faded away. I continued for a little longer, but then I, too, stopped going to the classes. After that, it became very difficult to stay motivated. I do pick up the guitar occasionally, but nothing comes out of it. I even started taking classes again, but that, too, went nowhere and I was out of there within another month or two. Now I am 35 years old and pretty much devoid of turning dream in to reality. I may not be able to learn to play the guitar in this lifetime. So don’t do the things I have done, and you have a good shot at becoming an awesome guitar player.

In my opinion, having a passion for music speeds up the process a lot, especially if you're having fun. I started my lifelong love for music from elementary school, playing the cheap plastic flutes they teach with there. Sure, what I played was nowhere impressive nor heart moving, but I was happy and entertained by it. Many days I would be seen sitting in the school yard, playing all sorts of music from pop to classic. In my junior high, I joined the Chinese music orchestra club and started learning to play the cello. As one could imagine, this club wasn't one of the popular clubs, and only had around 15 to 20 people in it. However, inspite to our small size, we were able to play and have tons of fun jamming together. Who said you can only play traditional Chinese music? The instrument you play doesn't limit you to what you can play. Finally, I joined a rock club in high school, at first as a drummer. I had a hard time learning it due to the fact that you can't take it home with you, so instead I borrowed a rusty abandoned guitar laying around the corner, strung some new strings on it and took it home. From there I was a fast learner, and soon exceeded my older schoolmates. Why? Because I didn't play to impress girls or for attention. I played for the fun of it, and when you're having fun, it numbs the pain from forming blisters. Tips: YouTube is a great media platform to find inspiration and all your favorite covers to learn.Start by learning songs that you like, simplify the songs if necessary.Don't play to impress, play to entertain yourself first. Birds of a feather flock together, and you will meet more and more music enthusiasts like yourself!

To become a better guitar player, you have to be open to learning things you may not believe matter. While finger exercises are good (do not buy that POS spring loaded finger thing - it's crap and was debunked back in the 1980s when it came out), the best finger exercise is to play the guitar. Reading music is not critical to becoming a better guitar player, but it is critical to becoming a more versatile and capable, and employable guitar player in studio work and for "orchestral" playing gigs (no TAB there). All guitar players begin with basic open chords. But many only go on to learn basic Barre chords, the major and minor forms, and that is where it ends for them. If you really want to improve, to be better, you have to learn the "jazz" chords, all those other chords with the funny names like a 13b5b9 an stuff like that. And to make your chord knowledge really excel, you need to learn four different ways to play every chord you know - four differing forms (fingerings), because any given chord is everywhere on the neck. Scales are also important, the modes, pentatonic minor and pentatonic major, the harmonic minor, chromatic and whole tone scales are a good place to start. Rhythm is critical to understand. If you cannot capture the "feel" of a swing/shuffle, and do it right, you will never find the pocket, the groove a song requires which uses this feel. Tied to rhythm is time keeping skill. You have to know how to count things out so you will know when things happen, how to capture that elusive strum pattern (rhythm) being played by the guitar player you're listening to. So working with a metronome is very important (electronic, not pendulum). Get a stand alone metronome, so you're not a slave to your phone or computer ( which should be elsewhere than where you practice). All my students learn this stuff, and more, like multiple styles to see how things work because Rock doesn't cover every possibility to show how things work. Nor does Blues, or Jazz, or Pop... There's definitely more, of course. But this should give you a firm basis from which to draw to get you going in the right direction. (IF you cite any of this elsewhere, please include your source - me. I offer this for free to you. Please honour my authorship. Thank you.)

Practice often. As they say, practice makes perfect! And let me tell you from personal experience, it DOES pay off. Never give up.This, i feel, is most important. If you can't get something down, move on and come back to it. Because anything that you do whether it is easy or hard at first, it gets easier. Know the difference between practicing too much and not enough. If you miss a practice or two, it's okay. Don't procrastinate about it though.   Have at least one song to practice that you are passionate about at all times. If  you don't like to practice, you most likely won't choose to practice. And if you don't practice, you won't get better. Lastly, have a good attitude even if you can get a certain chord/chord progression down. Don't beat yourself up! Why? Because it doesn't help the situation. If you don't have a good attitude, then you won't enjoy playing. And that's why we all play- to enjoy the music.

Like the obvious answer, practice, but.. it really depends on what you consider to be a good guitarist. Are you going for solo guitar, playing tunes and pieces with no singing and or other instrumentation. This type of playing requires quite a bit more study and is a bit more “naked” if you will. Mistakes and stutters stand out more when it’s just you playing your axe by itself. Now, if you want to be a good accompanying guitarist for your own singing or someone else, you might get away with a bit less polish. Having played guitar for many years, I have hit several plateaus where it just seemed like I was going nowhere. The key here, at least for me, was to just stick with it a bit longer. Learn an open tuning, try finger style, pick up a slide, learn a song outside of your comfort zone. I will switch to mandolin or ukulele as well, these will give you a new perspective on playing a stringed instrument. Also, find a local jam group, as this will push you along as well, playing with others especially someone more accomplished will help tremendously. Lessons from a professional will help in the beginning, avoiding some bad habits and learning some theory is always good. Above all, pickup you guitar EVERYDAY ! Just noodling around is fine too. If it’s not any FUN, you will not get very good. Even if you don’t and still have fun, then you have accomplished more than a lot of folks. Playing guitar is therapeutical, soothes your soul and will give you lifelong enjoyment. Peace Den

Passion for music , dedication to learn and practice are the three main prerequisites to play decent guitar. When you will start to play guitar, you will probably go to a professional guitarist or will buy a book which will give you some basics. Whatever may be the case the first few weeks is going to be a challenge for you, and that is the time when most people give up. In the beginning you will find yourself stuck into practicing basics and getting your fingers accustomed to the string and learning the theoretical part , while others like your trainer or your friends are playing some fancy chords and music.Don't let this demotivate you. Just survive first 3 or 4 months with the practice then you will find that you have found yourself a new companion that will stay with you forever , learning will be so much fun and you will be too excited every time you hear something new or somebody playing something new. You are sad, you will search your guitar, your are happy , scared or anxious whatever may be the emotion , it will be there for you Just the feeling that you can play guitar will give you so much happiness that cannot be defined. So start your practice now and Happy learning.

A guitar is fun to play . when you are alone or when you want to play and sing with friends. From personal experience, I can tell you not to worry about being good at guitar .Just play because you want to and because  its fun. Don't worry about others being better than you because your talent comes with time and experience. Also start slowly with easy songs.. And then move to songs which are more complicated to play . Starting off with a complicated sing to play will kill your interest because it is highly unlikely that you will be able to pull it off with less practice . and the key to being a better at anything you do is practice. It'll take time but you will get there. All the best.

Practice seems a lot of work. Play your guitar! Enjoy! Have fun as much as you can. Explore things you have never before your guitar and a bit musical theory as well. "Learn from as many places you can find. Listen to all the guitar players you really like/love. When you play their licks make it something of your own" - Marty Friedman. Originality! "Find/know your musical personality" - Rob Chapman. Record/listen to your stuff to keep a track of where you're at. Jam with other musicians. Play the blues and then get into jazz. Remember, "scales are very important!" - Jamey Aebersold. "It matters how many different shapes you know and how fast you can play them." - Guthrie Govan. Look up articulations and "play each note in a finesse" - Artie Traum. One day you will be able to play what you hear in your head! Cheers!

you have to practice a lot… make sure u hold the pick correctly and practice the finger practice always even if you are not a novice. whenever you practice always remember this one golden rule.. clarity above speed…. You want the notes and chords you play to be clear, then you can work on increasing the speed .. never leave practice and always keep trying new songs of your genre or choice twice every month.. Once you get the hang of it try to make your own music , i.e innovation and experimentation… Make sure to record your jams as we all tend to forget what we played. read a lot of theories/books watch people on youtube w.r.t the genre you wish to play in. and keep practicing… Music is a field where you always have scope to improve and it simply requires time.

Practice practice practice. No one ever became good at something by sitting around with their thumb up their ass. Practice whenever you have free time. You can play scales and work on your dexterity while you watch TV, for christ’s sake. Listen to different genres of music. Try to play along with the songs on the radio. Make friends with other musicians and try to jam together. You’ll start to learn how to improvise in the middle of a song and that will make you feel like a god when you create something in the moment like that. Start playing!

Practise, and plenty of it. But that’s not all. It must be quality practise. Simply putting in the hours isn’t always enough. If you hire a tutor (and you really should) they will set you homework. If they are a good tutor, they will set you the right thimgs to work on so that you get some quality practise between lessons. Also, listen to plenty of music. A wise man once said that the late Johnny Winter played more guitar than anybody else because he listened to more guitar than anybody else. So for today, here is some nice playing to listen to by yours truly. Enjoy, and excuse the plug! NEVER GOING BACK AGAIN -originally recorded by Fleetwood Mac

First, listen to enough guitar music to know specifically what style of music you want to play. This enables you to pick individual artists you’d hope to emulate and learn from. Then watch YouTube or other Internet sites to watch carefully as your favorite artists perform. This also is goal-oriented practicing and playing. Find tutorials that best motivate you and inform you in the styles you’ve chosen. Don’t waste time idling or noodling with your guitar. Don’t call it practice if you’re lying on the sofa, or watching TV. Rather, start each practice with a goal or goals in mind. I have never had any problem devoting time to practicing guitar, because I enjoy it so much, but I know of guitarist friends who’ve scheduled time each day to play. And they set deadlines to get ready for performances or make recordings. So set goals, manage your time and for inspiration, always go back to the guitar masters you’ve chosen to study and grow toward.

Don’t ask me. Been playing for 40 years, and don’t consider myself a good guitarist. But I love it, and have made many friends through it, and maybe that’s more important. If pressed, I’d probably say the most important things are: get a half-decent guitar - you don’t need to spend a fortune, but get something that isn’t a bastard to play.learn to play the music you like. You’ll be much more inclined to stick with it.after a while, have a few lessons from a sympatico tutor. A bit later, have some more.play with other people. Start a band. Write some songs or some music. Remember that music is a social thing.

Along with all of the technical, and practical requirements there is one aspect to becoming a good guitar player which is often not expressed sufficiently. Yes, we need to get started, approach the learning, practice our movements and finger positions. We need to know about music, we need to play with others, we need to obtain the best quality instrument which suits us, that we can. But, above all else, we have to want it, we have to desire to be good and this provides the emotional energy you need to aspire and to continually improve. We need to want guitar playing so badly that we cannot allow it to fade away or dwindle into being yet another ‘hobby’. Guitar is a calling, a way of life and we must want it very much.

The best thing you can do isl to have the guitar in your hands as much as possible. Watching tv, sitting on the porch, every time you can. When I was teaching (probably 500+ students over time), I could always tell the students who were more comfortable with the guitar in their hands. Even if you only want to learn 3 chords and play Kumbaya, being “as one” with that guitar will make you improve more quickly.

practice MORE, and practice BETTER. better means practice what will improve your musicianship. you may find out what that is by studying online, by reading, by seeking wisdom/advice from players you know and admire, or by taking paid lessons. choosing a teacher may be limited to “the only guy in town,” or choosing from ten who all charge the same fee. shop around. learn from friends first. get advice from players you admire, respect. learn how to play, not how to “get that sound.”

There is nothing better for your picking skills than time spent picking alongside others. If you're the worst player, who cares. Just keep playing. Like golf, I was once reminded by someone who was heavily engaged in playing… “You haven't spent enough time playing golf [guitar] to justify getting upset for sucking.” Play as many hours each day as you can.

You can become a good guitarist by first deciding that it something your going to do. Everything we do in life is based on our decisions. When we get up, when we go to bed, eat, etc. We decide everything in our personal lives. So if you want to become a good guitar player, you first must decide to. Then once the decision is made, you set out to acquire the tools necessary to get you there. A guitar (obviously) some learning material (books youtube videos, friends who play guitar etc) and if at all possible, a good guitar tutor. The last thing can make a world of difference. Why? Because a good guitar tutor that you make a connection with can teach you things that will help you overcome your learning curve. Help you to progress faster with short cuts from personal experience. A good tutor you make a connection with can make you feel good about learning and make you want to continue your study for years to come. Which will make you become a good guitarist. If you need more insight to becoming a good guitarist, Be sure to grab my free training guide 5 Step Practice Routine Also, here’s a short video I made that might help you out. Good luck on your journey of becoming a good guitarist and if you need any additional help, feel free to let me know. Best of luck to you and take care. Dwayne jenkins7 Ways To Improve Your Guitar Playing On A Daily Basis

Think of a note in your head,then find it on the fretboard. Keep doing this over and over and over,keeping in mind that there is always more than one place to find a note on a guitar fretboard. Teach yourself to move efficiently and articulate each note clearly. Look at any video of Jimi Hendrix or any jazz guitar player,notice they aren’t flailing around or even seem to be working hard,relaxing while you play and economy of movement are absolutely key to getting better. Never stay in a comfort zone for too long either.

I really believe that the answer is simple: accomplishment. You’ll get as good as you want to be at whatever you want to be if you start making any kind of accomplishment in that field. So with guitar, start making simple accomplishments, and you will also be making progression. Then simply keep accomplishing what you want until you feel sufficiently accomplished. I should note that you might discover that your goals may turn out to be overly-ambitious ones. The only way you will be able to continue making accomplishments is to make those goals smaller. The advice I give to my students is, if you allot an hour for practice, set a goal that you think that you can accomplish in 5 minutes. Then if you feel like playing more, go right ahead, you have allotted yourself the time; why not? If not, then put it down, you accomplished something anyway. I hope this helps, and good luck.

Having this attitude is not what will get you there. Playing an instrument requires hours and weeks and years of dedication. If you don’t enjoy the ride then you will never have the motivation to be consistent. Make it your main objective to be able to play and make music today and everyday and your secundary objective to be a good guitar player. Then one day you will wake up and you will notice how much you have evolved since you began.

I can think of a few different answers, but I won't belabor you with all of them. I would start simply with structure. You can get structure from an instructor or even some online sites (musiciswin.com, guitartricks.com, artistworks.com, tomhess.com). These places will teach you how to practice until you're able to develop your own unique method. And make sure you use a metronome with clearly defined goals (for example, playing 16th notes clearly at 120 beats per minute). Good luck!

Since many answers already have been posted, let me tell you a short story that happened here in Brazil, with a most famous Brazilian guitarrist, named Luís Bonfá. He was once interviewed on a TV show by Hebe Camargo, a famous Brazilian artist who had this interview program on TV. After he finished playing a song in his guitar, she asked him what would it take to be able to play the guitar. His answer was: It takes three things: 1 - You have to have a guitar. So if you don’t have one yet, go buy one. 2 - You have to like your guitar. If you don’t like it you won’t play it. 3 - The most dificult part: you have to make the guitar like you.

Believe in yourself… And most importantly, Practice!! Practice as much as you can.. Discover your weaknesses and rectify them. And try to experiment with the instrument. Surely, you'll one day be amazed by your own guitar playing skills.

Find a source of motivation. It'll help you keep going. Do not underestimate this step.Find some good source of learning guitar.Being regular is the key here.Do not skip music theory.Jam with others and go live ( after a certain point of time)
"Sometimes you may want to throw the guitar away. But if you stick to it you will be rewarded" - JIMI HENDRIX
Play in a band
Practice!
